Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Subcutaneous and Intraarticular Indwelling Vacuum Drainage in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 111 patients undergoing primary TKA were randomised

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either subcutaneous or intraarticular indwelling vacuum drainage

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates whether subcutaneous indwelling vacuum drainage offers advantages over intraarticular indwelling vacuum drainage in primary TKA.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was blood loss, measured by hemoglobin decrease and transfusion requirements, assessed over 5 days post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 56 patients were randomised to the subcutaneous group and 55 to the intraarticular group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean vacuum drainage volume was significantly lower in the subcutaneous group (140 mL) compared to the intraarticular group (352 mL).

Harms.evidence: No severe adverse events were reported in either group.
